description_full: The Harbor Grand Hotel in Far Harbor riffs on the Bar Harbor Grand Hotel in downtown Bar Harbor. The in-game version keeps the seaside block and Victorian styling while portraying the interior as a crumbling maze of flooded rooms and feral residents.

description_short: Monorail departure point carrying visitors to the Nuka-World park.
description_full: The Nuka-World Transit Center sits west of Boston as the monorail gateway to the amusement park DLC. Its grand station facade and rail yard mirror Worcester's Union Station, serving as a clear analog for a regional hub repurposed for theme-park access.

name_real: Six Flags New England, Agawam, MA
description_short: Central hub of the raider-run Nuka-World amusement park.
description_full: Nuka-Town USA in Fallout 4 is the entry plaza to Nuka-World, ruled by raider gangs. It is a strong analog to Six Flags New England in Agawam, sharing the riverside setting and clustered rides while turning the concourses into fortified bazaar streets.

name_real: Six Flags New England Kidzopolis Area, Agawam, MA
description_short: Corroded children's zone shrouded in Nuka-World's corrosive mist.
description_full: Kiddie Kingdom is the children’s ride sector of Nuka-World, saturated with corrosive mist. It parallels the kid-focused sections of Six Flags New England, using the same park footprint while replacing bright rides with decayed animatronics and trapped mascots.

name_real: Six Flags New England North End, Agawam, MA
description_short: Star-themed park sector patrolled by restored robots.
description_full: The Galactic Zone in Fallout 4 is a sci-fi themed section of Nuka-World defended by Star Control robots. It maps onto the northern ride clusters of Six Flags New England, with the game swapping coasters for retro-futuristic exhibits and a central mission control tower.

name_real: Six Flags New England Western Town, Agawam, MA
description_short: Western-themed park land overrun by malfunctioning cowboy bots.
description_full: Dry Rock Gulch in Fallout 4 recreates a frontier town inside Nuka-World. It corresponds to the western-themed area of Six Flags New England, keeping the boardwalk facades while populating them with robotic sheriff actors and hidden feral ghouls.

name_real: Six Flags New England Hurricane Harbor Area, Agawam, MA
description_short: Overgrown zoo and safari dome filled with mutated wildlife.
description_full: Safari Adventure is Nuka-World's zoo district in Fallout 4. It overlaps the waterpark and animal-themed edges of Six Flags New England, turning enclosures and splash zones into glass biodomes patrolled by gatorclaws and primates.

description_short: Scenic cliffside gazebo honoring Nuka-Cola's creator.
description_full: Bradberton Overlook in Fallout 4 is a hillside memorial to John-Caleb Bradberton above Nuka-World. It mirrors overlooks along the Holyoke Range south of the park, pairing wooded ridgelines with a small pavilion that the game outfits as a hidden bunker entrance.

name_real: Lizzie Borden House, Fall River, MA
description_short: Macabre stage-show mansion featuring the lethal Grandchester family.
description_full: The Grandchester Mystery Mansion in Fallout 4 is a haunted attraction inside Nuka-World. It riffs on notorious New England murder houses like the Lizzie Borden House in Fall River, adapting the Victorian facade and tour format into a weaponized funhouse.

description_short: Pre-war suburb where the Sole Survivor begins before Vault 111.
description_full: Sanctuary Hills is the Sole Survivor's neighborhood in Fallout 4. It is modeled on leafy suburbs north of Boston like Concord, keeping the cul-de-sacs and bridge over the river while shifting the layout to place Vault 111 in the nearby hills.

description_short: Tight urban scrap fort built in a former Boston service alley.
description_full: Hangman's Alley in Fallout 4 is a compact player settlement wedged between tall buildings. It corresponds to the narrow service alleys of Boston's North End, using the same brick canyons and fire escapes while adding barricades and rooftop shacks.

name_real: Boston University East Campus, Boston, MA
description_short: Ghoul-filled campus plaza near the Boston Public Library ruins.
description_full: College Square in Fallout 4 is a subway-adjacent plaza swarming with feral ghouls. It parallels the BU East Campus area along Commonwealth Avenue, preserving the rail median and collegiate storefronts while depicting them as gutted shells.

name_real: St. Thomas Aquinas Chapel, Nahant, MA
description_short: Coastal chapel seized by zealots hunting a runaway synth.
description_full: Nahant Chapel in Fallout 4 sits on the peninsula's shoreline, echoing small chapels like St. Thomas Aquinas in Nahant. The game retains the seaside hilltop setting while turning the sanctuary into an ambush site during the quest 'Human Error.'

description_short: Broadcast relay unlocking military distress signals in the northwest Commonwealth.
description_full: Relay Tower 0BB-915 is one of Fallout 4's raiseable radio masts. It stands in wooded hills resembling the telecom towers near Bedford, Massachusetts, keeping the forested ridge while adding extendable antenna rigs and supply crates.

name_real: Telecom Mast west of Carlisle, MA
description_short: Radio mast revealing hidden supply caches once powered.
description_full: Relay Tower 0DB-521 in Fallout 4 sits on a hilltop northwest of Boston. It is analogous to rural telecom masts west of Carlisle, Massachusetts, with the game converting a utility clearing into a small scavenger camp beside the extendable tower.

description_short: Robot-run greenhouse complex producing surplus mutfruit.
description_full: Graygarden in Fallout 4 is a greenhouse settlement operated by Mr. Handy robots. It parallels greenhouse clusters along the Fitchburg Line near Waltham, keeping the elevated rail bed and glass structures while adding hydroponic rigs and robot maintenance bays.

name_real: Jamaica Plain Municipal Building, Boston, MA
description_short: Derelict municipal hall rumored to hide a priceless treasure.
description_full: The Jamaica Plain Town Hall in Fallout 4 anchors a quest about the town's 'treasure.' It matches the municipal building and surrounding square in Boston's Jamaica Plain neighborhood, though the game collapses neighboring blocks and fills the hall with traps and ferals.

description_short: Swamped foundation turned into a player build site crawling with mirelurks.
description_full: Murkwater Construction Site in Fallout 4 is a flooded foundation south of Quincy. It reflects the marshy Fore River wetlands, preserving the waterlogged excavation pit while adding half-built framing and mirelurk nests the player must clear.

description_short: Haunted seaside mansion reclaimed from feral ghouls.
description_full: Croup Manor in Fallout 4 stands on a cliff above the Atlantic. It mirrors the Victorian seaside houses on Nahant Road, keeping the ocean views while depicting the structure as half-collapsed and packed with ferals until the Sole Survivor restores it.

description_short: Small farming homestead tucked into the southwest Commonwealth.
description_full: Somerville Place in Fallout 4 is a family farm the player can assist and claim as a settlement. Its name and location reference the real city of Somerville, using the same suburban farmland feel while simplifying the surrounding neighborhoods into open plots.

description_short: Foggy amusement pier leading into the swamps of Point Lookout.
description_full: The Point Lookout Boardwalk in Fallout 3's DLC evokes decaying seaside amusement piers. It parallels the Chesapeake Beach boardwalk on Maryland's western shore, with similar rides and piers reimagined as ruined stalls facing marshy bay water.

name_real: Point Lookout Lighthouse Manor, Scotland, MD
description_short: Gothic manor hiding the rival Calvert family brains in Point Lookout.
description_full: Calvert Mansion in Fallout 3's Point Lookout DLC is a fortified estate above the bay. It aligns with the historic lighthouse area near Point Lookout State Park, turning the bluff-top homes into a booby-trapped stronghold contested by Desmond and Professor Calvert.

name_real: St. Mary's County Military Reservation, MD
description_short: Enclave prisoner camp featured in the Broken Steel add-on.
description_full: Turtledove Detention Camp appears in Fallout 3's Broken Steel DLC as an Enclave labor site. Its forested barracks mirror training ranges within the St. Mary's County military reservations, converted in-game into a fenced POW camp for wastelanders.

name_real: United States Marine Corps War Memorial, Arlington, VA
description_short: Frozen harbor monument marking the Anchorage Reclamation.
description_full: The Anchorage Memorial in Fallout 3 commemorates the liberation of Anchorage and becomes a mutant den. It occupies the Potomac waterfront in a position analogous to Arlington's USMC War Memorial, adapting a war statue and reflecting pool into a flooded combat space.

name_real: Industrial Cannery Site, Falls Church, VA
description_short: Chinese-owned pre-war food factory hiding covert operations.
description_full: Mama Dolce's factory in Fallout 3 is a Chinese front producing canned goods and secret intel. Its brick warehouse setting fits industrial zones in Falls Church, Virginia, with the game expanding underground access tunnels to a hidden signal station.

name_real: Great Falls Park Caves, McLean, VA
description_short: Collapsed metro spur overrun by feral bears beneath the Potomac bluffs.
description_full: The Yao Guai Tunnels in Fallout 3 wind beneath rocky Potomac bluffs and spill into ruined rails. They parallel cave-filled ravines in Great Falls Park, keeping the steep terrain while adding derailed cars and hibernating mutated bears.

name_real: Davison Army Airfield, Fort Belvoir, VA
description_short: Brotherhood staging ground for the assault on Adams Air Force Base.
description_full: Maxson Air Force Base in Fallout 3's Broken Steel DLC is a Brotherhood forward base. It aligns with the air facilities at Fort Belvoir, such as Davison Army Airfield, reflecting the same wooded runways while transforming hangars into vertibird pads and staging tents.

name_real: Kolob Terrace, Zion National Park, UT
description_short: Tribal camp allied with Joshua Graham in Zion Canyon.
description_full: Dead Horse Camp in the Honest Hearts DLC sits along Zion's high plateaus. It corresponds to campsites on the Kolob Terrace of Zion National Park, with the game adding Dead Horse totems and white-painted tents while keeping the mesa vistas.

name_real: Three Marys Canyon, Zion National Park, UT
description_short: Waterfall-lined canyon providing passage across Zion.
description_full: Three Marys in Fallout: New Vegas marks a scenic canyon with hanging bridges and Sorrows patrols. It maps directly to Three Marys Canyon in Zion National Park, retaining the waterfalls and narrow slot paths while adding wooden walkways and camp totems.

description_short: Rockfall-choked pass separating tribal territories in Zion.
description_full: Red Gate in the Honest Hearts DLC is a landslide-blocked pass guarded by White Legs. It corresponds to the cliff-lined eastern approaches to Zion National Park, mirroring the red sandstone switchbacks while dramatizing the blockage with toppled boulders.

name_real: Lake Mead B-29 Crash Site, NV
description_short: Submerged bomber resting on the floor of Lake Mead.
description_full: The Sunken B-29 in Fallout: New Vegas is a real-world crash site of a B-29 Superfortress in Lake Mead. The game preserves its location and orientation underwater, adding salvage cables for the NCR to raise it during 'Volare!'.

description_short: Small roadside outpost between the Mojave Outpost and Searchlight.
description_full: The Nipton Road Reststop in Fallout: New Vegas sits along Highway 164, serving travelers and Jackal raiders. It reflects real roadside stops between Searchlight and Nipton, repurposed in-game with boarded shops and an abandoned gas station.

name_real: Nevada Test and Training Range Badlands, NV
description_short: Tornado-scoured canyon of silos and collapsed highways from Lonesome Road.
description_full: The Divide in Fallout: New Vegas is a blasted canyon of missile impacts and storms. It draws from the remote badlands of Nevada's Test and Training Range along US-6/50, using similar arid mesas and abandoned military infrastructure exaggerated for apocalyptic drama.

name_real: Groom Lake Area, Nevada Test Site
description_short: Research crater at the center of Old World Blues' Big MT facility.
description_full: The Big MT Sink in Fallout: New Vegas sits in a crater ringed by think tanks and labs. It is an analog to the secretive research basins around Groom Lake at the Nevada Test Site, translating restricted desert valleys into a walled science preserve full of robo-brains.

name_real: La Fonda on the Plaza, Santa Fe, NM
description_short: Cursed pre-war resort trapped in an endless poisonous cloud.
description_full: The Sierra Madre Casino in Fallout: New Vegas: Dead Money is a sealed art-deco resort. It evokes historic Southwestern hotels like La Fonda in Santa Fe, sharing adobe facades and a central plaza while relocating the analog to a fictional ghost city filled with toxic fog.

description_short: Collapsed missile silo launch site breached in Lonesome Road.
description_full: Ashton Silo Control Station in Fallout: New Vegas is a destroyed ICBM facility players infiltrate. Its remote desert runway setting mirrors the decommissioned Wendover Air Force Base along the Utah-Nevada border, adapted into a bombed-out silo complex.

description_short: Luxury lakeside resort ruins now prowled by fiends and cazadores.
description_full: Lake Las Vegas appears in Fallout: New Vegas as a partially drained resort area southeast of the Strip. It matches the real planned community around Lake Las Vegas in Henderson, keeping the artificial lake and villa layout while aging them into cracked stucco shells.

name_real: North Fork Virgin River Camps, Zion National Park, UT
description_short: Tribal encampment of the peaceful Sorrows along Zion's river.
description_full: Sorrows Camp in Honest Hearts hosts the Sorrows tribe beside the North Fork of the Virgin River. It parallels riverside campsites in Zion National Park, retaining the cottonwoods and canyon walls while adding whitehandprint totems and cooking pits.

name_real: Kolob Arch Backcountry Caves, Zion National Park, UT
description_short: Sacred Sorrows cavern used for Joshua Graham's preparations.
description_full: Angel Cave in Fallout: New Vegas is a hidden cavern sanctuary for the Sorrows. It evokes backcountry caves near Kolob Arch in Zion National Park, preserving the red rock chambers while adding tribal shrines and stockpiled weapons for the White Legs war.

name_real: Dragon Gate, Grant Avenue, San Francisco, CA
description_short: Iconic entry arch to San Francisco's Chinatown seen in Fallout 2 and the TV series.
description_full: The Chinatown Gate marks the entrance to San Francisco's Chinatown in Fallout 2, appearing again in Amazon's Fallout series establishing shots. It is the same Dragon Gate on Grant Avenue, used intact on-screen and referenced as the pre-war gateway to Shi-controlled districts.

description_short: Ghoul-run city built in the ruins of pre-war Bakersfield.
description_full: Necropolis in the original Fallout is a city of ghouls occupying Bakersfield. The mapping keeps the Highway 99 corridor and desert outskirts of Bakersfield, with the game replacing neighborhoods by flooded sewers and the hidden Vault 12 beneath.

name_real: Bass Harbor Head Light, Tremont, ME
description_short: Rocky lighthouse watched by Children of Atom fanatics in Far Harbor.
description_full: Brooks Head Lighthouse in Fallout 4 guards the southern tip of Mount Desert Island, claimed by zealots. It is a clear analog to Bass Harbor Head Light near Tremont, preserving the cliffside beacon and keeper's house while adding radioactive fog shrines.

name_real: Long Pond Camps, Mount Desert Island, ME
description_short: Hermit's coastal cabin that becomes the player’s Far Harbor base.
description_full: Old Longfellow's Cabin in Fallout 4 belongs to the grizzled hunter helping the Sole Survivor. It mirrors camps along Long Pond on Mount Desert Island, keeping the lakeside dock and pine forest while outfitting the shack with Far Harbor traps and stills.

description_short: Coal plant powering Nuka-World and final raider control point.
description_full: The Nuka-World Power Plant in Fallout 4 sits north of the park as a looming smokestack complex. It parallels the retired Mount Tom power station along the Connecticut River, using the same riverside industrial footprint as an analog generation hub.

description_short: Scrapyard outside Nuka-World filled with scavengers and bots.
description_full: The Nuka-World Junkyard in Fallout 4 sprawls over trash heaps east of the park monorail. It corresponds to the Bondi's Island landfill on the Connecticut River, turning the real disposal site into a rusted camp of robots and raiders picking through refuse.

name_real: Six Flags Riverfront Amphitheater, Agawam, MA
description_short: Stage and hillside pavilion honoring Nuka-Cola's creator.
description_full: Bradberton Amphitheater in Fallout 4 overlooks Nuka-Town with a memorial to John-Caleb Bradberton. It mirrors the riverfront amphitheater at Six Flags New England, reimagining its lawn seating as a fenced shrine and raider meeting ground.

name_real: Six Flags Main Street Pavilion, Agawam, MA
description_short: Operators' polished headquarters above Nuka-Town's streets.
description_full: The Parlor in Fallout 4 serves as the Operators' casino-like base within Nuka-Town. Its second-story balcony and stage match the park's main street pavilion at Six Flags New England, adapted into a leather-clad raider clubhouse overlooking the central thoroughfare.

name_real: Bottling Riverfront Pad, Six Flags New England, MA
description_short: Soda-themed river plant filled with quantum security turrets.
description_full: Fallout 4's Nuka-Cola Bottling Plant anchors the west end of the Nuka-World park with vats and tasting lines. It parallels the industrial staging pad along the Connecticut River behind Six Flags New England, converting backstage service docks into a branded bottling tour.

name_real: Springfield Science Museum Seymour Planetarium, MA
description_short: Space show dome inside the Galactic Zone's ruined midway.
description_full: The Starlight Interstellar Theater in Fallout 4 hosts star-core exhibits and malfunctioning projectors. It reflects the planetarium at the Springfield Science Museum, using a similar domed hall as an analog before overlaying Nuka-Cola branding and security bots.

name_real: USAF Lincoln Labs Radar Test Range, Bedford, MA
description_short: Military scrap yard storing a dormant sentry bot and practice range.
description_full: The Robotics Disposal Ground in Fallout 4 is a fenced pit of broken drones north of Boston. It parallels radar and drone test ranges near Hanscom Field and Lincoln Labs, turning a real defense scrapyard layout into a playable demolition site with a buried sentry bot.

description_short: Collapsed relay dish field beside the Fort Hagen approach.
description_full: Fallout 4's Fort Hagen Satellite Array scatters toppled dishes and a hostile robot staging ground west of Boston. It aligns with Cold War uplink stations around Sudbury and Marlborough, treating their cleared pads as analog antenna farms guarding the highway.

name_real: Boston Edison Power Substation, Dorchester, MA
description_short: Underground robot factory seized from the Rust Devils by Ada and the Mechanist.
description_full: The Mechanist's Lair in Fallout 4: Automatron hides beneath a ruined industrial block south of downtown. Its brick substation shell matches Boston Edison power facilities in Dorchester, serving as an analog warehouse converted into a multi-level robot foundry.

name_real: Downtown Crossing Office Block, Boston, MA
description_short: Collapsed RobCo tower where the Sole Survivor meets Ada in Automatron.
description_full: In Fallout 4's Automatron quest, the RobCo Sales & Service Center is a downtown ruin filled with rogue robots. It maps to the office towers near Downtown Crossing, using the same street grid as an analog corporate lobby overtaken by Mechanist forces.

name_real: Former Whittenton Mills complex, Taunton, MA
description_short: Toy factory ruin occupied by rogue robots and scavengers.
description_full: The Wilson Atomatoys Factory in Fallout 4 is a multi-story mill packed with protectrons and assembly lines. Its riverside brick layout mirrors the old Whittenton Mills in Taunton, adapting the textile complex into an analog toy plant with collapsing catwalks.

name_real: GE Aviation Lynn River Works, Massachusetts
description_short: Automated robot plant churning out Mr. Gutsy units north of Boston.
description_full: Fallout 4's General Atomics Factory is a hazardous assembly line full of aggressive bots. It parallels the GE River Works facility in Lynn, using the same waterfront industrial footprint as an analog robotics plant tucked beside the Saugus River.

description_short: Drive-in near Nuka-World used as a raider staging area in the wasteland.
description_full: Eden Meadows Cinema in Fallout 4 sits outside Nuka-World as a ruined drive-in theater with a downed plane. It aligns with the site of the former West Springfield drive-in, converting its gravel lot and screen berm into a raider ambush ground and workshop space.

description_short: Foggy bowling alley hideout on Mount Desert Island.
description_full: Beaver Creek Lanes in Fallout 4's Far Harbor DLC is a collapsed bowling alley full of trappers. It parallels bowling centers in Ellsworth near Acadia, using the roadside boxy footprint as an analog refuge overtaken by raiders and wildlife.

description_short: Quaking mire packed with feral ghouls and sunken shacks in Far Harbor.
description_full: Cranberry Island Bog in Fallout 4 mirrors the tidal marshes south of the Cranberry Isles off Mount Desert Island. The DLC converts the mudflats and scattered docks into a hazardous wading ground dotted with half-sunk homes and lurking ghouls.

name_real: Beaver Ridge Wind Project, Freedom, ME
description_short: Line of collapsed turbines that power Far Harbor's fog condensers.
description_full: The Acadia Wind Farm in Fallout 4 strings broken turbines across a ridge on the mainland. It parallels the Beaver Ridge wind project in central Maine, using the same hilltop turbine spacing as an analog power site crippled by storms and feral creatures.

name_real: South Portland Harbor Fish Shacks, ME
description_short: Raiders nest in decaying seaside shanties along the Far Harbor route.
description_full: Haddock Cove in Fallout 4 is a small inlet cluttered with raider shacks and fishing boats. It evokes the working docks of South Portland, adapting real lobster shanties into a post-war camp that players must clear.

description_short: Marshy campsite overtaken by super mutants south of Far Harbor town.
description_full: Rayburn Point in Fallout 4 once hosted campers along the inshore waters before mutants moved in. It parallels campgrounds along the Mount Desert Narrows, converting picnic shelters and RV pads into flooded fighting positions amid radiation pockets.

description_short: Smuggler grotto used by a synth-hunting trapper in Far Harbor.
description_full: Brooks' Sea Caves in Fallout 4 hide stashes and a kidnapped synth beneath tidal rock arches. They echo the natural sea caves near Bar Island by Bar Harbor, using the same granite openings as an analog smuggling den exposed at low tide.

name_real: Winter Harbor Radar Annex Bluff, ME
description_short: Radiant cliffside shrine tended by Far Harbor's zealots.
description_full: This Children of Atom Shrine in Fallout 4 overlooks the ocean from a rocky outcrop east of the island. It aligns with the cliffs near the former Winter Harbor radar annex, turning antenna footings into an analog pilgrimage site bathed in fog and radiation.

name_real: Roswell UFO Crash Site area, NM
description_short: Secret saucer crash that begins the Mothership Zeta adventure.
description_full: Fallout 3 hides an Alien Crash Site northwest of DC, leading to the Mothership Zeta DLC. Its layout mirrors cultural depictions of the Roswell incident near Corona, New Mexico, using desert coordinates as an analog for a downed craft that beams the player aboard.

description_short: BoS Outcast bunker running the Operation: Anchorage combat simulator.
description_full: The Outcast Anchorage Outpost in Fallout 3 is a fortified metro junction where players enter the VR assault. It corresponds to Fort Independence near Arlington, adapting the historic pentagonal earthwork into an analog command bunker guarded by defector paladins.

name_real: Port of Anchorage petroleum terminal, AK
description_short: Icy fuel yard fought over in the Operation: Anchorage simulation.
description_full: In Fallout 3's Operation: Anchorage, the fuel depot mission targets a waterfront oil yard. It mirrors the real Port of Anchorage petroleum terminals, using the same shoreline tank farms as an analog battleground layered with snowfields and Chinese PLA troops.

name_real: Carrie Furnace Steel Works, Rankin, PA
description_short: Smog-choked mill district filled with wild trogs and ingot hunts.
description_full: The Pitt Steel Yard in Fallout 3's DLC sends players through rusted blast furnaces and catwalks. It aligns with the Carrie Furnace industrial complex outside Pittsburgh, turning its towering stacks and ore sheds into a hazardous scavenging maze.

description_short: Ash-covered stronghold of Ashur and the Pitt raider leadership.
description_full: Haven Overlook in Fallout 3 crowns the skyline of the Pitt as the raider citadel. It parallels the U.S. Steel Tower in downtown Pittsburgh, using the same dominating footprint as an analog command tower wrapped in slave scaffolding and gun nests.

name_real: Strip District Produce Terminal, Pittsburgh, PA
description_short: Makeshift bazaar trading steel, slaves, and cure rumors beneath smokestacks.
description_full: The Pitt Market in Fallout 3 sits inside arched freight bays that shelter raider merchants. It echoes the Pittsburgh Produce Terminal in the Strip District, adapting its long brick concourse into an analog marketplace filled with shacks and chained workers.

name_real: Hot Metal Street Rail Spur, Pittsburgh, PA
description_short: Collapsed tram tunnels crawling with feral trogs under the Pitt.
description_full: The Trog Tramway in Fallout 3 links the mill to downtown through broken elevated rails. It mirrors Pittsburgh's Hot Metal Street and river rail spurs, using the same industrial bridges as an analog passage now prowled by devolved workers.

description_short: Secret lab wing beneath Desmond's estate in Point Lookout.
description_full: The hidden laboratories under Calvert Mansion in Fallout 3 extend the estate into a fortified bunker. They reflect military communications bunkers scattered around Point Lookout, using similar reinforced corridors as an analog hideout for Desmond's experiments.

description_short: Deathclaw burrow hidden in the collapsed drainage under Old Olney.
description_full: The Old Olney Sewers in Fallout 3 connect ruined streets to a nest of Deathclaws and Enclave patrols. They correspond to the storm tunnels beneath Olney, Maryland, turning mundane drainage lines into a deadly underground lair.

description_short: Prisoner camp in the Big MT crater holding hologram-guarded inmates.
description_full: Little Yangtze in Fallout: New Vegas' Old World Blues DLC is a walled POW yard patrolled by holograms. It draws from Cold War detention camps and radar sites on the Nevada Test Site, using a desert blockhouse layout as an analog internment zone.

name_real: Yucca Flat Test Dome, Nevada National Security Site
description_short: Old World Blues robot arena guarded by a cybernetic scorpion.
description_full: The Forbidden Zone Dome in Fallout: New Vegas sits on the rim of Big MT as a showdown arena. It parallels the geodesic test domes in Yucca Flat, reimagining the research enclosures as an analog lair for Dr. Mobius's experiments and giant robo-scorpions.

name_real: St. Vincent Hospital, Santa Fe, NM
description_short: Red cloud-choked medical wing in the Sierra Madre Villa.
description_full: The Villa Clinic in Fallout: New Vegas: Dead Money is a crumbling hospital servicing the casino workers. It evokes regional hospitals like St. Vincent in Santa Fe, using adobe styling and courtyards as an analog before overlaying toxic gas and ghost people.

name_real: Groom Lake Research Dispensary Site, NV
description_short: High-tech medical pod chamber inside Big MT's Sink dome.
description_full: The Auto-Doc Suite in Fallout: New Vegas provides surgical upgrades within the Sink base. Its sterile lab aesthetic mirrors small research dispensaries around Groom Lake, using those secretive clinics as an analog for the Old World Blues upgrade room.

name_real: Three Marys Falls area, Zion National Park, UT
description_short: Sorrows tribe cavern system with water pools and hanging bridges.
description_full: Three Marys Cavern in Fallout: New Vegas is a sheltered hideout behind waterfalls in Zion. It aligns with the Three Marys Falls area, using the same creek-fed alcoves as an analog refuge populated by tribals and cazadores.

name_real: Canyon Overlook Trail, Zion National Park, UT
description_short: Scenic ridge path overlooking the Sorrows' valley in Honest Hearts.
description_full: The Zion Canyon Overlook in Fallout: New Vegas provides vistas and a firefight with White Legs. It parallels the real Canyon Overlook Trail in Zion, translating the switchbacks and sheer drop-offs into a hazardous hiking route filled with survivalists.

description_short: Expansion of Junktown's outer piles where prospectors trade parts.
description_full: The Junktown Scrapheap in Fallout is a sprawl of rusted cars and shanties beyond Killian's gates. It corresponds to the auto salvage yards of Apple Valley near Barstow, using the same desert heaps as an analog marketplace run by scavengers.

name_real: Fourth Street Market, Los Angeles, CA
description_short: Historic quarter of the Hub controlled by merchants and caravans.
description_full: Hub Old Town in the original Fallout mixes brick warehouses and caravan depots. It mirrors the brick wholesale blocks of downtown Los Angeles around Fourth Street, serving as an analog trading ward where rival caravans and mercenaries stage deals.

name_real: San Diego Naval Base Pier 1, CA
description_short: Refugee piers outside the irradiated Glow, mentioned in Fallout 2 and the TV series.
description_full: Dayglow's docks serve as the lifeline for survivors living outside the contaminated Glow crater. They parallel the naval piers of San Diego Bay, using the same long wharf layout as an analog harbor where caravans, NCR patrol boats, and refugees converge.

description_short: Brotherhood-manned gate controlling access into the Boneyard ruins.
description_full: The Brotherhood of Steel gate into the Boneyard in Fallout is fortified with sandbags and checkpoints. It corresponds to guarded access points along Sepulveda Boulevard near Westchester, serving as an analog highway chokepoint controlling traffic into ruined Los Angeles.

name_real: Sutro Baths Terrace, San Francisco, CA
description_short: Cult enclave on San Francisco's cliffs worshipping starships and enlightenment.
description_full: The Hubologist Compound in Fallout 2 occupies coastal ruins with a view of the ocean. It parallels the Sutro Baths terrace near Lands End, adapting the concrete foundations and overlook into an analog cult campus preparing for a doomed shuttle launch.

description_short: Uranium mine powering the mixed mutant town of Broken Hills.
description_full: Broken Hills in Fallout 2 relies on a uranium mine worked by super mutants and humans. It aligns with the Copper Mountain Mine near Nevada's border, using the same pithead-and-camp layout as an analog resource site fueling the settlement's reactor.

description_short: Pristine civic dome where Vault 8's overseers rule the city.
description_full: The Council Dome in Fallout 2's Vault City is a gleaming administrative hall for the descendants of Vault 8. It parallels civic centers in Carlin, Nevada, using a similar planned grid and central hall as an analog of a carefully maintained vault-born capital.

name_real: ESE Big E Monorail Spur, West Springfield, MA
description_short: Boarding platform where raiders ambush the monorail to Nuka-World.
description_full: The Nuka-Express Monorail Platform in Fallout 4 is a high concrete station serving the park shuttle. It parallels the monorail spur constructed for the Big E fairgrounds in West Springfield, adapting its elevated dock into a raider trap above the highway.

name_real: Six Flags Arena Plaza, Agawam, MA
description_short: Robot gladiator arena inside the Galactic Zone midway.
description_full: RobCo Battlezone in Fallout 4 pits visitors against waves of combat bots for tickets. It maps to the arena plaza space at Six Flags New England, converting a show pavilion into a circular combat pit packed with malfunctioning robots.

name_real: Main Midway Arcade, Six Flags New England, MA
description_short: Ticket arcade where raiders gamble for Nuka-World prizes.
description_full: The Nuka-Cade in Fallout 4 sits at Nuka-Town's core with skee-ball and prize counters. It parallels arcade halls on the Six Flags New England midway, adapting the same footprint into a raider-run prize den accepting caps and tokens.

name_real: Six Flags Overflow Picnic Grove, Agawam, MA
description_short: Small campsite for Hubologist pilgrims beside the star rides.
description_full: In Fallout 4's Nuka-World DLC, a group of Hubologists tents near the Galactic Zone seeking a fusion core. Their camp mirrors overflow picnic groves west of the Six Flags rides, turning shade shelters into an analog staging area for the star-worshipping cult.

name_real: White Sands Test Facility Clean Room, NM
description_short: Freezing chamber aboard the alien ship where captives awaken.
description_full: The Cryo Lab in Fallout 3's Mothership Zeta DLC holds abducted humans in suspended animation. It draws on clean-room test bays at White Sands, using similar sterile pods as an analog while relocating the scene to orbit for the abduction narrative.

name_real: Kincaid Park Bunker Site, Anchorage, AK
description_short: Hidden PLA listening post infiltrated during the Anchorage simulation.
description_full: During Operation: Anchorage in Fallout 3, players assault a covert Chinese listening post carved into icy cliffs. It parallels bunker sites in Kincaid Park outside Anchorage, using the wooded coastal bluffs as an analog hiding spot for radio operators.

description_short: Gladiatorial pit called the Hole where slaves fight for freedom.
description_full: The Pitt Arena in Fallout 3 hosts brutal matches for entertainment and manumission. It aligns with indoor arenas like the Petersen Events Center in Pittsburgh, adapting the domed seating bowl into an analog bloodsport venue within the smoggy city.

description_short: Blocked highway canyon leading into Lonesome Road's Divide.
description_full: The Canyon Wreckage in Fallout: New Vegas seals the courier's path with destroyed overpasses and NCR patrols. It parallels Grapevine Canyon near Laughlin, using the same narrow wash and cliff walls as an analog entry scarred by collapsed bridges.

description_short: Highly irradiated blast crater packed with marked men in Lonesome Road.
description_full: Courier's Mile in Fallout: New Vegas is a towering crater left by a nuclear detonation during Lonesome Road. It mirrors subsidence craters on the Nevada National Security Site, using one of the test ground depressions as an analog battlefield coated in radiation.

name_real: MGM Grand Monorail Operations, Las Vegas, NV
description_short: NCR-guarded station powering the Strip monorail to Camp McCarran.
description_full: The Monorail Control Building in Fallout: New Vegas sits on the Strip as NCR-secured transit infrastructure. It parallels the Las Vegas Monorail operations facility near the MGM Grand, adapting the real control hub into a guarded transport node amid the war.

name_real: Staff Housing, Six Flags New England, MA
description_short: Barracks-style lodging block for park staff now used by raiders.
description_full: The Nuka-World Employee Dorms in Fallout 4 sit behind the park gates as dilapidated housing for raiders and traders. They parallel staff lodging clusters behind Six Flags New England, adapting the service quarters into a looted bunkhouse on the edge of the wasteland park.

description_short: Hidden grove where Harold has grown into a sentient tree.
description_full: Oasis in Fallout 3 is a secretive community protecting Harold, whose body has merged with a great tree. The grove lies in cliffs north of DC and parallels the wooded hollows of Great Falls Park, using the same river overlooks as a secluded refuge for the Treeminders.

description_short: Radioactive sinkhole filled with Children of Atom zealots.
description_full: The Crater of Atom in Fallout 3 is a bomb-blasted depression inhabited by the Children of Atom. It sits east of DC in the same corridor as Takoma Park, mirroring the neighborhood's railroad cut turned into a glowing worship site by the radiation cultists.

name_real: Sugar Grove Listening Posts Region, West Virginia
description_short: Remote satellite dish cluster guarded by mercenaries in the wastes.
description_full: SatCom Array NN-03d in Fallout 3 is a field of radar dishes used by raiders and Talon Company. Its isolated mountain setting matches former NSA listening posts near Sugar Grove, West Virginia, serving as an analog Cold War station watching the skies.

description_short: War-torn neighborhood contested by Enclave and Brotherhood squads.
description_full: Takoma Park in Fallout 3 is a ruined suburb besieged by the Enclave. It occupies the real Maryland neighborhood of Takoma Park, keeping its rowhouse streets and Metro access while portraying the zone as a frontline between factions.

name_real: Rock Creek Park Tunnels, Washington, DC
description_short: Collapsed highway tunnel packed with traps and raider ambushes.
description_full: The Rockland Car Tunnel in Fallout 3 connects Georgetown to the Mall through a wrecked underground highway. It parallels the Rock Creek and Potomac Parkway tunnels, using the same curved bore under parkland as an ambush-filled corridor.

name_real: Former Nuka-Cola HQ Site, Crystal City, VA
description_short: Corporate tower of Nuka-Cola now crawling with feral ghouls.
description_full: Nuka-Cola Corporation Headquarters in Fallout 3 is a branded office block full of cola memorabilia. It stands just outside DC in Crystal City, mirroring the area's commercial high-rises and metro connections while converting a modern office tower into a ghoul-infested landmark.

description_short: Flooded suburb overrun by feral ghouls and stagnant water.
description_full: Forest Grove Marsh in Fallout 4 is a submerged neighborhood filled with feral ghouls. It mirrors the low-lying ponds near Waushakum in Framingham, adapting the cul-de-sacs and boardwalks into a waterlogged trap for unwary scavengers.

name_real: Trailer Park West of Framingham, MA
description_short: Gutted trailer park used by raiders and patrolled Mr. Handies.
description_full: Fiddler's Green Trailer Estates in Fallout 4 is a fenced trailer park stalked by ferals and rogue Mister Handies. It sits west of Boston along Route 9, echoing real trailer communities outside Framingham with the same looped driveway and clustered mobile homes.

name_real: Jersey Street Service Tunnel, Fenway Area, MA
description_short: Hidden sewer lair beneath the ballpark district near Diamond City.
description_full: The Fens Street Sewer in Fallout 4 hides a trap-ridden lair below the ballpark neighborhood. It aligns with service tunnels beneath Jersey Street at Fenway Park, turning maintenance corridors into a raider dungeon under Diamond City's outfield walls.

name_real: Former Chemical Labs, South Boston, MA
description_short: Experimental gas lab filled with unstable toxins and malfunctioning turrets.
description_full: HalluciGen, Inc. in Fallout 4 is a pre-war chemical weapons lab full of hallucinogenic gas experiments. Its brick warehouse footprint south of downtown mirrors Boston's former industrial labs, adapting the multi-story factory into a chaotic combat test site.

description_short: Derelict Irish-themed pub with a raider bar fight arena inside.
description_full: The Shamrock Taphouse in Fallout 4 is a gutted Irish pub turned raider den. It sits in the Financial District and mirrors the cluster of historic bars near the Rose Kennedy Greenway, turning a narrow tavern footprint into a scrap-built fighting pit.

description_short: Greaser-themed power armor garage run by the Atom Cats gang.
description_full: Atom Cats Garage in Fallout 4 is a hot-rod themed power armor chop shop. It parallels automotive yards in Quincy and Braintree near the Fore River, using the same cinderblock bays and fenced lot as an analog hangout for the retro-styled gang.

name_real: Industrial Park North of Quincy, MA
description_short: Family-run metal shop harboring a lone deathclaw.
description_full: O'Neill Family Manufacturing in Fallout 4 is a small industrial building hiding a captured deathclaw. The site parallels light industrial parks north of Quincy along Route 3A, adapting a brick warehouse bay into a deathclaw pen amid scrap heaps.

description_short: Wartime bunker network commandeered by raiders and Scav bosses.
description_full: The Federal Ration Stockpile in Fallout 4 is a fortified cave storing pre-war food caches. It aligns with military depot bunkers around Fort Devens, using the same earth-covered magazines as an analog hoard now occupied by raiders and Red Tourette's crew.

name_real: Suffolk County Elementary Site, Revere, MA
description_short: Abandoned school full of pink-slime test vats and feral teachers.
description_full: Suffolk County Charter School in Fallout 4 is a ruined elementary school overtaken by pink-slime food experiments. It matches the peninsula classroom complex in Revere, converting the coastal school footprint into a cautionary tale of failed wartime nutrition programs.

description_short: Secret intelligence bunker monitored by the ghoulish Agent Edwards.
description_full: Federal Surveillance Center K-21B in Fallout 4 hides beneath the hills west of Cambridge, filled with terminals that recorded synths. It parallels underground signals intelligence bunkers at Fort Devens, repurposing a communications vault into a feral ghoul-infested data hub.

description_short: Flooded drain culvert connecting Malden streets to a Raider hideout.
description_full: Malden Drainage in Fallout 4 is a short storm drain hideout used during the Silver Shroud quests. It parallels the drainage culverts under the Fellsway in Malden, turning maintenance tunnels into a secret entry for mobsters and raiders.

name_real: Dorchester Auto Salvage Yards, Boston, MA
description_short: Scrap yard piled high with crushed cars and a hidden bomb collar stash.
description_full: Big John's Salvage in Fallout 4 is an auto junkyard south of Boston overrun by raiders. It mirrors Dorchester's salvage lots along the Southeast Expressway, using stacked cars and a crane tower as an analog scrapyard with a dark family bunker beneath.

name_real: MBTA Red Line Abandoned Platform, Quincy, MA
description_short: Secret subway platform leading into the O'Neill tunnel warrens.
description_full: O'Neill Station in Fallout 4 is a hidden subway stop connecting to raider-filled service tunnels. It parallels unused MBTA platforms south of Quincy Center, adapting the abandoned red line spur into a clandestine base beneath the highway.

name_real: Dry Wells Basin, Nevada Test Site
description_short: Legion slave pit nuked into a crater in Lonesome Road's finale.
description_full: Dry Wells in Fallout: New Vegas is a Legion crucifixion site later obliterated by a nuke. Its desert basin parallels cratered test grounds south of the Nevada National Security Site, using the same arid flats as a grim analog execution ground.

name_real: Klamath River Delta Tribal Lands, CA
description_short: Sulik's tribal home of the Umbra, a riverside camp of hunters.
description_full: The Umbra Tribe Village in Fallout 2 is Sulik's home, a riverside camp built around fishing and spirits. It parallels tribal lands near the Klamath River mouth in far northern California, using similar riverbank clearings as an analog settlement.

description_short: Simple tribal camp near Vault 15 visited during NCR expansion.
description_full: The Primitive Tribe in Fallout 2 lives in makeshift huts near Vault 15, resisting NCR assimilation. Their camp fits the sparse tent sites around Oasis Valley near Beatty, Nevada, using the same desert springs as an analog gathering place.

name_real: EPA Western Ecology Lab, Corvallis, OR
description_short: Hidden pre-war environmental vault rumored in Fallout 2 cut content.
description_full: The EPA Facility in Fallout 2's restoration mod is a sealed environmental research vault. It aligns with the EPA ecology labs in Corvallis, Oregon, using the Pacific Northwest campus setting as an analog for a high-tech bunker studying flora and fauna.

description_short: Circular open-pit mine with experimental rock-eating robots.
description_full: The Crater Mining Site in Fallout 2's add-on content is a round open pit filled with malfunctioning robo-miners. It parallels the open pits in the Darwin mining district east of the Sierra Nevada, using a similar circular excavation as an analog hazardous dig.

name_real: Potter's Field near New Reno, NV
description_short: Desolate graveyard where New Reno families bury their secrets.
description_full: Golgotha in Fallout 2 is a lonely graveyard outside New Reno used to disappear enemies. It corresponds to the potter's fields outside Reno, using the desert cemetery plots as an analog burial ground lined with shallow graves and mob victims.

name_real: Desert Diner Ruins off I-80, Nevada
description_short: Easter-egg diner filled with classic Fallout characters in a dream.
description_full: The Caf of Broken Dreams in Fallout 2 is a surreal desert diner populated by familiar faces. It fits the abandoned highway diners along I-80 in Nevada, using a lonely roadside building as an analog dreamscape stopover.

description_short: Ghoul-run Republic of Dave link used by the Family of vampires.
description_full: Meresti Metro Station in Fallout 3 hides the Family of reclusive cannibals. It corresponds to rail yards near Glenmont on the Red Line, converting an outlying maintenance station into a subterranean lair with side tunnels leading to their lair.

name_real: Key Bridge Park Camp, Arlington, VA
description_short: Riverside campsite used by Outcasts and wanderers beside the Potomac.
description_full: The F. Scott Key Trail & Campground in Fallout 3 provides a riverside camp under the Key Bridge. It mirrors the recreation fields and camps along the Mount Vernon Trail near Key Bridge Park, adapting picnic shelters into makeshift tents.

name_real: Wendover Air Force Base Control, Utah
description_short: Central command building for the bombed-out Hopeville missile base.
description_full: Hopeville Missile Base HQ in Fallout: New Vegas is the shattered command center explored during Lonesome Road. It parallels abandoned control blocks at Wendover Air Force Base on the Utah-Nevada line, turning Cold War launch offices into a collapsed command post amid missile silos.
